channel.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
channel.description: is it possible to add the java\bin directory to the path with java? Or to modify the registry

item.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Why use java at all. It’s a windows specific program so no need for java. And definitely not for jni, since that’s just being gay. Writing a java application, with use of jni while you could just use only c/c++ instead.

Yes I know the title said java, but a few posts down he mentioned java is not required.

Read full topic

i dont see the great thing of that over jni… the application would be non-portable anyways, so what it is that you gain from using your method over jni…

nothing

item.source: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java

item.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Use java.util.prefs.WindowsPreferences. The bonus is: once you invoke the constructor with the right parameters you can then use the original Preferences interface to do what you want without reflection or other ugly hacks. Simple and easy.

Read full topic

item.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:15, topic:308208”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=404340.msg3000117#msg3000117 date=1255903497]
java.util.prefs is a fairly new package to aid with the registry.

Preferences userPref = Preferences.userRoot();
userPref.put(“key”, “value”);

will put value in HKCU\Software\JavaSoft\Prefs\key
[/quote]
but does it allow you to set registry keys like PATH??[/quote]
I’m sure the native side of the implementation requires full names. You could either use reflection on that class or start using sun.* classes and achieve what you want.

Read full topic

item.source: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java

item.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Modify the following registry key, easy with c/c++. Little bit more complicated with java obviously, but doable.

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SessionManager\Environment\Path

Read full topic
item.source: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java

item.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

abraham2119:

on linux im pretty sure its as easy as modifying a file

.bashrc if you are using bash. But most package managers place symlinks in /usr/bin making no need to touch PATH.

As to this thread, you would have to modify the registry.

Read full topic

item.source: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java

item.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:3, topic:308208”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=404340.msg2992845#msg2992845 date=1255388130]
if you want to modify the path variable for use only within your application’s shell, you can simply do:

Runtime.getRuntime().exec("set PATH=directory");assuming you are on windows

edit: to do it in a portable manner you can modify the map instance returned by ProcessBuilder.environment()
[/quote]
no you cant do that, cause set isnt an executable, its a command inside of cmd[/quote]oh in that case just use the portable alternative i provided

Read full topic
item.source: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java

Runtime.getRuntime().exec("set PATH=directory");assuming you are on windows

edit: to do it in a portable manner you can modify the map instance returned by ProcessBuilder.environment()[/quote]
no you cant do that, cause set isnt an executable, its a command inside of cmd

item.title: Adding the java\bin directory to path with java
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

if you want to modify the path variable for use only within your application’s shell, you can simply do:

Runtime.getRuntime().exec("set PATH=directory");assuming you are on windows

edit: to do it in a portable manner you can modify the map instance returned by ProcessBuilder.environment()

Read full topic
